articles.summary: Europe experienced its warmest March since records began. Globally, last month was the planet's second-warmest March on record, exceeded only by March in 2024. Many areas experienced driest March and others their wettest March for at least the past 47 years.

articles.title: March 2025 2nd-warmest on record, says Copernicus
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: March this year was the second-warmest ever globally, after March 2024. It was the 20th month of the last 21 that saw global-average surface air temperature that exceeded 1.5 degrees C over the pre-industrial level.  .

articles.title: Earth's upper mantle is revealing the deepest effect of human activity
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: As the Aral Sea has been drained by irrigation and dried up, Earth's upper mantle has risen up, lifting the emptied sea bed 7 millimetres per year. The mass loss on the surface has caused the Earth's surface to rise up.

articles.title: Việt Nam among Asian countries most vulnerable to climate change
articles.author: Vietnam News
articles.summary: The Asia-Pacific region will drive 60 per cent of the world's economic expansion in 2024. Several countries in the region are not ready to cope with climate shocks and the implications of transitioning to a greener system. Rising global economic uncertainty and deepening climate risks are also not making it easy for the fiscal and monetary policymakers.

articles.title: March second warmest on record, says EU climate body
articles.author: RTE
articles.summary: Last month was the second warmest March on record, according to EU Copernicus Climate Change Service. It was also the 20th time in the last 21 months that the average global surface air temperature was more than 1.5 degrees Celsius above the monthly pre-industrial level.

articles.title: Arctic winter sea ice shrinks to lowest level in 47 years
articles.author: Famagusta Gazette
articles.summary: Arctic winter sea ice shrank to its lowest March level since satellite monitoring began 47 years ago. Sea ice extent in March was 6 percent below the average. It's the fourth consecutive monthly record low for the time of year.   Â

articles.author: Mongabay

articles.title: German climate activist faces expulsion from Austria after ban
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Austria bans German climate activist Anja Windl for two years. Windl has been living in Austria for seven years and is known for her protests against climate change. She has one month to leave the country or she could be expelled from the EU member state.

articles.title: Cyber Threats Escalate: U.S. Tops Hacktivist DDoS Targets, But Australia And NZ Remain In The Crosshairs
articles.summary: The first quarter of 2025 saw a significant spike in cyber activity led by politically motivated hacktivist groups. The United States was the most targeted country for distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, accounting for 13.5% of global incidents. Cyberattack rates in the Asia-Pacific region are now 60% higher than the global average.

articles.title: How is climate change impacting farmworkers?
articles.summary: Even one degree of temperature change can have a devastating impact on farmworkers. St. Luke's Climate and Health Series on "Climate Change and Farming: Worker Protections and Community Resiliency" is on Wednesday, April 9th. Irene Ruiz, executive director of the Idaho Organization of Resource Councils and Amanda Blanchet, an emergency medicine physician assistant and the executive director at ICCH will give a preview.

articles.title: Former White House climate adviser talks climate, future with SRU community
articles.author: Zach Zimmerman
articles.summary: Ali Zaidi is the former White House National Climate Advisor under President Joe Biden. He spoke at Slippery Rock University's Robert M. Smith Student Center ballroom on Monday, April 7. The speech and Q&A session circled around climate change, policymaking and leadership. He talked about previously safe areas becoming more at risk to climate disasters and the financial impact of towns damaged by severe weather.
